The Age of APIs

The Age of APIs Erik Wilde: OpenAPI Fundamentals: The Value of OpenAPI

(3) Running on APIs

  • Systems use APIs internally to interconnect various technical components
  • Organizations use APIs strategically to allow teams to move faster
  • Business use APIs economically to establish and grow global products


The Age of APIs Erik Wilde: OpenAPI Fundamentals: The Value of OpenAPI

(4) API Value: Technical Drivers

  • Digital Transformation: Increasing number of digital channels and capabilities
  • Digital Decay: Decreasing time for which a channel can remain unchanged
  • Microservices: Moving away from monolithic architecture


The Age of APIs Erik Wilde: OpenAPI Fundamentals: The Value of OpenAPI

(5) API Value: Organizational Drivers

  • Cognitive Load: Isolating teams from the complexity of today's tech stacks
  • Team Interactions: Allowing teams to publish self-service building blocks
  • Team Effectiveness: Building platforms to increase team effectiveness


The Age of APIs Erik Wilde: OpenAPI Fundamentals: The Value of OpenAPI

(6) API Value: Business Drivers

  • API-based Products: Better business agility through better product development
  • Product APIs: Augmenting existing products with programmable features
  • API Products: Offering products that can consumed easily and globally


A Brief History of APIs

A Brief History of APIs Erik Wilde: OpenAPI Fundamentals: The Value of OpenAPI

(8) 1948: Structuring Code for Reuse

Source: Herman Goldstine and John von Neumann, "Planning and Coding Problems for an Electronic Computing Instrument", Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, 1947/1948.



A Brief History of APIs Erik Wilde: OpenAPI Fundamentals: The Value of OpenAPI

(9) 1968: First Light for API

Source: Ira W. Cotton, Frank S. Greatorex, "Data structures and techniques for remote computer graphics", Proceedings of the December Fall Joint Computer Conference AFIPS '68, Pages 533–544, https://doi.org/10.1145/1476589.1476661



A Brief History of APIs Erik Wilde: OpenAPI Fundamentals: The Value of OpenAPI

(10) From Local to Remote

  • Initially API only referred to local interfaces (same machine)
  • With the emergence of the Internet the scope of computing extended
  • Starting in 2000, network-based API was used widely
  • OpenAPI is firmly placed on the network-based side


A Brief History of APIs Erik Wilde: OpenAPI Fundamentals: The Value of OpenAPI

(11) From the Human Web to the Machine Web

  • 1990: First server at CERN
  • 1993: NCSA releases Mosaic browser
  • 1995: Amazon
  • 1998: Extensible Markup Language (XML)
  • 2000: SOAP
  • 2000: "Internet as a Service": Salesforce, eBay, Amazon
  • 2003: "Building Blocks": Delicious, Flickr, Facebook, Twitter, Foursquare, Twilio
